org.apache.freemarker.core

Interface ProcessingConfiguration

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    ParsingAndProcessingConfiguration, TopLevelConfiguration
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Configuration, Configuration.Builder, Configuration.ExtendableBuilder, Environment, MutableParsingAndProcessingConfiguration, MutableProcessingConfiguration, Template, TemplateConfiguration, TemplateConfiguration.Builder

    public interface ProcessingConfiguration
    Implemented by FreeMarker core classes (not by you) that provide configuration settings that affect template processing (as opposed to template parsing). New methods may be added any time in future FreeMarker versions, so don't try to implement this interface yourself!
    See Also:
    ParsingConfiguration, ParsingAndProcessingConfiguration

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static Object MISSING_VALUE_MARKER
      Useful as the default value parameter to {#getCustomSetting(Serializable, Object)}, because this value is not allowed for custom settings.

    • Method Detail

      • getLocale

        Locale getLocale()
        The locale used for number and date formatting (among others), also the locale used for searching localized template variations when no locale was explicitly specified where the template is requested.
        See Also:
        Configuration.getTemplate(String, Locale)

      • isLocaleSet

        boolean isLocaleSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getTimeZone

        TimeZone getTimeZone()
        The time zone to use when formatting date/time values. It Configuration-level default is the system time zone (TimeZone.getDefault()), regardless of the "locale" FreeMarker setting, so in a server application you probably want to set it explicitly in the Environment to match the preferred time zone of the target audience (like the Web page visitor).

        If you or the templates set the time zone, you should probably also set getSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone()!

        See Also:
        getSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone()

      • isTimeZoneSet

        boolean isTimeZoneSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone

        TimeZone getSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone()
        The time zone used when dealing with java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time values. Its Configuration-level defaults is null for backward compatibility, but in most applications this should be set to the JVM default time zone (server default time zone), because that's what most JDBC drivers will use when constructing the java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time values. If this setting is null FreeMarker will use the value of (getTimeZone()) for java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time values, which often gives bad results.

        This setting doesn't influence the formatting of other kind of values (like of java.sql.Timestamp or plain java.util.Date values).

        To decide what value you need, a few things has to be understood:

        • Date-only and time-only values in SQL-oriented databases are usually store calendar and clock field values directly (year, month, day, or hour, minute, seconds (with decimals)), as opposed to a set of points on the physical time line. Thus, unlike SQL timestamps, these values usually aren't meant to be shown differently depending on the time zone of the audience.
        • When a JDBC query has to return a date-only or time-only value, it has to convert it to a point on the physical time line, because that's what Date and its subclasses store (milliseconds since the epoch). Obviously, this is impossible to do. So JDBC just chooses a physical time which, when rendered with the JVM default time zone, will give the same field values as those stored in the database. (Actually, you can give JDBC a calendar, and so it can use other time zones too, but most application won't care using those overloads.) For example, assume that the system time zone is GMT+02:00. Then, 2014-07-12 in the database will be translated to physical time 2014-07-11 22:00:00 UTC, because that rendered in GMT+02:00 gives 2014-07-12 00:00:00. Similarly, 11:57:00 in the database will be translated to physical time 1970-01-01 09:57:00 UTC. Thus, the physical time stored in the returned value depends on the default system time zone of the JDBC client, not just on the content of the database. (This used to be the default behavior of ORM-s, like Hibernate, too.)
        • The value of the time_zone FreeMarker configuration setting sets the time zone used for the template output. For example, when a web page visitor has a preferred time zone, the web application framework may calls Environment.setTimeZone(TimeZone) with that time zone. Thus, the visitor will see java.sql.Timestamp and plain java.util.Date values as they look in his own time zone. While this is desirable for those types, as they meant to represent physical points on the time line, this is not necessarily desirable for date-only and time-only values. When sql_date_and_time_time_zone is null, time_zone is used for rendering all kind of date/time/dateTime values, including java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time, and then if, for example, time_zone is GMT+00:00, the values from the earlier examples will be shown as 2014-07-11 (one day off) and 09:57:00 (2 hours off). While those are the time zone correct renderings, those values are probably meant to be shown "as is".
        • You may wonder why this setting isn't simply "SQL time zone", that is, why's this time zone not applied to java.sql.Timestamp values as well. Timestamps in databases refer to a point on the physical time line, and thus doesn't have the inherent problem of date-only and time-only values. FreeMarker assumes that the JDBC driver converts time stamps coming from the database so that they store the distance from the epoch (1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC), as requested by the Date API. Then time stamps can be safely rendered in different time zones, and thus need no special treatment.
        See Also:
        getTimeZone()

      • isSQLDateAndTimeTimeZoneSet

        boolean isSQLDateAndTimeTimeZoneSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getNumberFormat

        String getNumberFormat()
        The number format used to convert numbers to strings (where no number format is explicitly given). Its Configuration-level default is "number". The possible values are:
        • "number": The number format returned by NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale)
        • "currency": The number format returned by NumberFormat.getCurrencyInstance(Locale)
        • "percent": The number format returned by NumberFormat.getPercentInstance(Locale)
        • "computer": The number format used by FTL's c built-in (like in someNumber?c).
        • A DecimalFormat pattern (like "0.##"). This syntax is extended by FreeMarker so that you can specify options like the rounding mode and the symbols used after a 2nd semicolon. For example, ",000;; roundingMode=halfUp groupingSeparator=_" will format numbers like ",000" would, but with half-up rounding mode, and _ as the group separator. See more about "extended Java decimal format" in the FreeMarker Manual.
        • If the string starts with @ character followed by a letter then it's interpreted as a custom number format. The format of a such string is "@name" or "@name parameters", where name is the key in the Map set by MutableProcessingConfiguration.setCustomNumberFormats(Map), and parameters is parsed by the custom TemplateNumberFormat.

      • isNumberFormatSet

        boolean isNumberFormatSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getCustomNumberFormats

        Map<String,TemplateNumberFormatFactory> getCustomNumberFormats()
        A Map that associates TemplateNumberFormatFactory-es to names, which then can be referred by the number_format setting with values starting with @name. The keys in the Map should start with an UNICODE letter, and should only contain UNICODE letters and digits (not _), otherwise accessing the custom format from templates can be difficult or impossible. The Configuration-level default of this setting is an empty Map.

        When the ProcessingConfiguration is part of a setting inheritance chain (Environment inherits settings from the main Template, which inherits from the Configuration), you still only get the Map from the closest ProcessingConfiguration where it was set, not a Map that respects inheritance. Thus, to get a custom format you shouldn't use this Map directly, but getCustomNumberFormat(String), which will search the format in the inheritance chain.

        Returns:
        Never null; unmodifiable Map.

      • getCustomNumberFormat

        TemplateNumberFormatFactory getCustomNumberFormat(String name)
        Gets the custom number format registered for the name. This differs from calling getCustomNumberFormats().get(name), because if there's ProcessingConfiguration from which setting values are inherited then this method will search the custom format there as well if it isn't found here. For example, MutableProcessingConfiguration.getCustomNumberFormat(String) will check if the Environment contains the custom format with the name, and if not, it will try Template.getCustomNumberFormat(String) on the main template, which in turn might falls back to calling Configuration.getCustomNumberFormat(String).

      • isCustomNumberFormatsSet

        boolean isCustomNumberFormatsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getBooleanFormat

        String getBooleanFormat()
        The string value for the boolean true and false values, intended for human audience (not for a computer language), separated with comma. For example, "yes,no". Note that white-space is significant, so "yes, no" is WRONG (unless you want that leading space before "no").

        For backward compatibility the default is "true,false", but using that value is denied for automatic boolean-to-string conversion (like ${myBoolean} will fail with it), only myBool?string will allow it, which is deprecated since FreeMarker 2.3.20.

      • isBooleanFormatSet

        boolean isBooleanFormatSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getTimeFormat

        String getTimeFormat()
        The format used to convert Date-s that are time (no date part) values to string-s, also the format that someString?time will use to parse strings.

        For the possible values see getDateTimeFormat().

        Its Configuration-level default is "", which is equivalent to "medium".

      • isTimeFormatSet

        boolean isTimeFormatSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getDateFormat

        String getDateFormat()
        The format used to convert Date-s that are date-only (no time part) values to string-s, also the format that someString?date will use to parse strings.

        For the possible values see getDateTimeFormat().

        Its Configuration-level default is "" which is equivalent to "medium".

      • isDateFormatSet

        boolean isDateFormatSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getDateTimeFormat

        String getDateTimeFormat()
        The format used to convert Date-s that are date-time (timestamp) values to string-s, also the format that someString?datetime will use to parse strings.

        The possible setting values are (the quotation marks aren't part of the value itself):

        • Patterns accepted by Java's SimpleDateFormat, for example "dd.MM.yyyy HH:mm:ss" (where HH means 24 hours format) or "MM/dd/yyyy hh:mm:ss a" (where a prints AM or PM, if the current language is English).

        • "xs" for XML Schema format, or "iso" for ISO 8601:2004 format. These formats allow various additional options, separated with space, like in "iso m nz" (or with _, like in "iso_m_nz"; this is useful in a case like lastModified?string.iso_m_nz). The options and their meanings are:

          • Accuracy options:
            ms = Milliseconds, always shown with all 3 digits, even if it's all 0-s. Example: 13:45:05.800
            s = Seconds (fraction seconds are dropped even if non-0), like 13:45:05
            m = Minutes, like 13:45. This isn't allowed for "xs".
            h = Hours, like 13. This isn't allowed for "xs".
            Neither = Up to millisecond accuracy, but trailing millisecond 0-s are removed, also the whole milliseconds part if it would be 0 otherwise. Example: 13:45:05.8

          • Time zone offset visibility options:
            fz = "Force Zone", always show time zone offset (even for for java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time values). But, because ISO 8601 doesn't allow for dates (means date without time of the day) to show the zone offset, this option will have no effect in the case of "iso" with dates.
            nz = "No Zone", never show time zone offset
            Neither = always show time zone offset, except for java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time, and for "iso" date values.

          • Time zone options:
            u = Use UTC instead of what the time_zone setting suggests. However, java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time aren't affected by this (see getSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone() to understand why)
            fu = "Force UTC", that is, use UTC instead of what the time_zone or the sql_date_and_time_time_zone setting suggests. This also effects java.sql.Date and java.sql.Time values
            Neither = Use the time zone suggested by the time_zone or the sql_date_and_time_time_zone configuration setting (getTimeZone() and getSQLDateAndTimeTimeZone()).

          The options can be specified in any order.

          Options from the same category are mutually exclusive, like using m and s together is an error.

          The accuracy and time zone offset visibility options don't influence parsing, only formatting. For example, even if you use "iso m nz", "2012-01-01T15:30:05.125+01" will be parsed successfully and with milliseconds accuracy. The time zone options (like "u") influence what time zone is chosen only when parsing a string that doesn't contain time zone offset.

          Parsing with "iso" understands both extend format and basic format, like 20141225T235018. It doesn't, however, support the parsing of all kind of ISO 8601 strings: if there's a date part, it must use year, month and day of the month values (not week of the year), and the day can't be omitted.

          The output of "iso" is deliberately so that it's also a good representation of the value with XML Schema format, except for 0 and negative years, where it's impossible. Also note that the time zone offset is omitted for date values in the "iso" format, while it's preserved for the "xs" format.

        • "short", "medium", "long", or "full", which that has locale-dependent meaning defined by the Java platform (see in the documentation of DateFormat). For date-time values, you can specify the length of the date and time part independently, be separating them with _, like "short_medium". ("medium" means "medium_medium" for date-time values.)

        • Anything that starts with "@" followed by a letter is interpreted as a custom date/time/dateTime format, but only if either Configuration.getIncompatibleImprovements() is at least 2.3.24, or there's any custom formats defined (even if custom number format). The format of such string is "@name" or "@name parameters", where name is the name parameter to getCustomDateFormat(String), and parameters is parsed by the custom number format.

        Its Configuration-level default is "", which is equivalent to "medium_medium".

      • isDateTimeFormatSet

        boolean isDateTimeFormatSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getCustomDateFormats

        Map<String,TemplateDateFormatFactory> getCustomDateFormats()
        A Map that associates TemplateDateFormatFactory-es to names, which then can be referred by the date_format/date_format /datetime_format settings with values starting with @name. The keys in the Map should start with an UNICODE letter, and should only contain UNICODE letters and digits (not _), otherwise accessing the custom format from templates can be difficult or impossible. The Configuration-level default of this setting is an empty Map.

        When the ProcessingConfiguration is part of a setting inheritance chain (Environment inherits settings from the main Template, which inherits from the Configuration), you still only get the Map from the closest ProcessingConfiguration where it was set, not a Map that respects inheritance. Thus, to get a custom format you shouldn't use this Map directly, but getCustomDateFormat(String), which will search the format in the inheritance chain.

        Returns:
        Never null; unmodifiable Map.

      • getCustomDateFormat

        TemplateDateFormatFactory getCustomDateFormat(String name)
        Gets the custom date or time or date-time format registered for the name. This differs from calling getCustomDateFormats.get(name), because if there's ProcessingConfiguration from which setting values are inherited then this method will search the custom format there as well if it isn't found here. For example, MutableProcessingConfiguration.getCustomNumberFormat(String) will check if the Environment contains the custom format with the name, and if not, it will try Template.getCustomDateFormat(String) on the main template, which in turn might falls back to calling Configuration.getCustomDateFormat(String).

      • isCustomDateFormatsSet

        boolean isCustomDateFormatsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getTemplateExceptionHandler

        TemplateExceptionHandler getTemplateExceptionHandler()
        The exception handler used to handle exceptions occurring inside templates. Its Configuration-level default is TemplateExceptionHandler.DEBUG_HANDLER. The recommended values are:
        • In production systems: TemplateExceptionHandler.RETHROW_HANDLER
        • During development of HTML templates: TemplateExceptionHandler.HTML_DEBUG_HANDLER
        • During development of non-HTML templates: TemplateExceptionHandler.DEBUG_HANDLER

        All of these will let the exception propagate further, so that you can catch it around Template.process(Object, Writer) for example. The difference is in what they print on the output before they do that.

        Note that the TemplateExceptionHandler is not meant to be used for generating HTTP error pages. Neither is it meant to be used to roll back the printed output. These should be solved outside template processing when the exception raises from Template.process. TemplateExceptionHandler meant to be used if you want to include special content in the template output, or if you want to suppress certain exceptions.

      • isTemplateExceptionHandlerSet

        boolean isTemplateExceptionHandlerSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getArithmeticEngine

        ArithmeticEngine getArithmeticEngine()
        The arithmetic engine used to perform arithmetic operations. Its Configuration-level default is BigDecimalArithmeticEngine.INSTANCE. Note that this setting overlaps with ParsingConfiguration.getArithmeticEngine().

      • isArithmeticEngineSet

        boolean isArithmeticEngineSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getObjectWrapper

        ObjectWrapper getObjectWrapper()
        The object wrapper used to wrap objects to TemplateModel-s. Its Configuration-level default is a DefaultObjectWrapper with all its setting on default values, and incompatibleImprovements set to Configuration.getIncompatibleImprovements().

      • isObjectWrapperSet

        boolean isObjectWrapperSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getOutputEncoding

        Charset getOutputEncoding()
        Informs FreeMarker about the charset used for the output. As FreeMarker outputs character stream (not byte stream), it's not aware of the output charset unless the software that encloses it tells it with this setting. Some templates may use FreeMarker features that require this information. Setting this to null means that the output encoding is not known.

        Its Configuration-level default is null.

      • isOutputEncodingSet

        boolean isOutputEncodingSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getURLEscapingCharset

        Charset getURLEscapingCharset()
        The URL escaping (URL encoding, percentage encoding) charset. If (null), the output encoding (getOutputEncoding()) will be used. Its Configuration-level default is null.

      • isURLEscapingCharsetSet

        boolean isURLEscapingCharsetSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getNewBuiltinClassResolver

        TemplateClassResolver getNewBuiltinClassResolver()
        The TemplateClassResolver that is used when the new built-in is called in a template. That is, when a template contains the "com.example.SomeClassName"?new expression, this object will be called to resolve the "com.example.SomeClassName" string to a class. The default value is TemplateClassResolver.UNRESTRICTED_RESOLVER. If you allow users to upload templates, it's important to use a custom restrictive TemplateClassResolver or TemplateClassResolver.ALLOWS_NOTHING_RESOLVER.

      • isNewBuiltinClassResolverSet

        boolean isNewBuiltinClassResolverSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getAPIBuiltinEnabled

        boolean getAPIBuiltinEnabled()
        Specifies if ?api can be used in templates. Its Configuration-level is false (which is the safest option).

      • isAPIBuiltinEnabledSet

        boolean isAPIBuiltinEnabledSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getAutoFlush

        boolean getAutoFlush()
        Whether the output Writer is automatically flushed at the end of Template.process(Object, Writer) (and its overloads). Its Configuration-level default is true.

        Using false is needed for example when a Web page is composed from several boxes (like portlets, GUI panels, etc.) that aren't inserted with #include (or with similar directives) into a master FreeMarker template, rather they are all processed with a separate Template.process(Object, Writer) call. In a such scenario the automatic flushes would commit the HTTP response after each box, hence interfering with full-page buffering, and also possibly decreasing performance with too frequent and too early response buffer flushes.

      • isAutoFlushSet

        boolean isAutoFlushSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getShowErrorTips

        boolean getShowErrorTips()
        Whether tips should be shown in error messages of errors arising during template processing. Its Configuration-level default is true.

      • isShowErrorTipsSet

        boolean isShowErrorTipsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getLogTemplateExceptions

        boolean getLogTemplateExceptions()
        Specifies if TemplateException-s thrown by template processing are logged by FreeMarker or not. The default is true for backward compatibility, but that results in logging the exception twice in properly written applications, because there the TemplateException thrown by the public FreeMarker API is also logged by the caller (even if only as the cause exception of a higher level exception). Hence, in modern applications it should be set to false. Note that this setting has no effect on the logging of exceptions caught by #attempt; those are always logged, no mater what (because those exceptions won't bubble up until the API caller).

      • isLogTemplateExceptionsSet

        boolean isLogTemplateExceptionsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getLazyImports

        boolean getLazyImports()
        Specifies if <#import ...> (and Environment.importLib(String, String)) should delay the loading and processing of the imported templates until the content of the imported namespace is actually accessed. This makes the overhead of unused imports negligible. A drawback is that importing a missing or otherwise broken template will be successful, and the problem will remain hidden until (and if) the namespace content is actually used. Also, you lose the strict control over when the namespace initializing code in the imported template will be executed, though it shouldn't mater for well written imported templates anyway. Note that the namespace initializing code will run with the same locale as it was at the point of the <#import ...> call (other settings won't be handled specially like that).

        The default is false (and thus imports are eager) for backward compatibility, which can cause perceivable overhead if you have many imports and only a few of them is used.

        This setting also affects auto-imports, unless you have set a non-null value with getLazyAutoImports().

        See Also:
        getLazyAutoImports()

      • isLazyImportsSet

        boolean isLazyImportsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getLazyAutoImports

        Boolean getLazyAutoImports()
        Specifies if auto-imports will be lazy imports. This is useful to make the overhead of unused auto-imports negligible. If this is set to null, getLazyImports() specifies the behavior of auto-imports too. The default value is null.

      • isLazyAutoImportsSet

        boolean isLazyAutoImportsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getAutoImports

        Map<String,String> getAutoImports()
        Adds invisible #import templateName as namespaceVarName statements at the beginning of the main template (that's the top-level template that wasn't included/imported from another template). While it only affects the main template directly, as the imports will create a global variable there, the imports will be visible from the further imported templates too.

        It's recommended to set the lazyAutoImports setting to true when using this, so that auto-imports that are unused in a template won't degrade performance by unnecessary loading and initializing the imported library.

        If the imports aren't lazy, the order of the imports will be the same as the order in which the Map iterates through its entries.

        When the ProcessingConfiguration is part of a setting inheritance chain (Environment inherits settings from the main Template, which inherits from the Configuration), you still only get the Map from the closest ProcessingConfiguration where it was set, not a Map that respects inheritance. But FreeMarker will walk the whole inheritance chain, executing all auto-imports starting from the ancestors. If, however, the same auto-import namespaceVarName occurs in multiple ProcessingConfiguration-s of the chain, only the one in the last (child) ProcessingConfiguration will be executed.

        If there are also auto-includes (see getAutoIncludes()), those will be executed after the auto-imports.

        The Configuration-level default of this setting is an empty Map.

        Returns:
        Never null

      • isAutoImportsSet

        boolean isAutoImportsSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getAutoIncludes

        List<String> getAutoIncludes()
        Adds an invisible #include templateName at the beginning of the main template (that's the top-level template that wasn't included/imported from another template).

        The order of the inclusions will be the same as the order in this List.

        When the ProcessingConfiguration is part of a setting inheritance chain (Environment inherits settings from the main Template, which inherits from the Configuration), you still only get the List from the closest ProcessingConfiguration where it was set, not a List that respects inheritance. But FreeMarker will walk the whole inheritance chain, executing all auto-imports starting from the ancestors. If, however, the same auto-included template name occurs in multiple ProcessingConfiguration-s of the chain, only the one in the last (child) ProcessingConfiguration will be executed.

        If there are also auto-imports (getAutoImports()), those imports will be executed before the auto-includes, hence the namespace variables are alrady accessible for the auto-included templates.

        Returns:
        An unmodifiable List; not null

      • isAutoIncludesSet

        boolean isAutoIncludesSet()
        Tells if this setting is set directly in this object. If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the setting mights returns a default value, or returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or throws an CoreSettingValueNotSetException.

      • getCustomSetting

        Object getCustomSetting(Serializable key)
                 throws CustomSettingValueNotSetException
        Retrieves the value of a custom setting. Custom settings are key-value pairs associated to a ProcessingConfiguration object, that the FreeMarker core doesn't try to interpret. They are like configuration settings added dynamically (as opposed to in compilation time), where each custom setting is treated as an individual setting. So where predefined configuration settings used to have isXxxSet, unsetXxx, and setXxx methods, custom settings have these too, with a key (the identifier of the custom setting) as an extra argument (see isCustomSettingSet(Serializable), MutableProcessingConfiguration.setCustomSetting(Serializable, Object), MutableProcessingConfiguration.unsetCustomSetting(Serializable)).

        When the ProcessingConfiguration is part of a setting inheritance chain (Environment inherits settings from the main Template, which inherits from the Configuration), this method will search the custom setting in the whole inheritance chain, until it finds it.

        To prevent key clashes (and for better performance), it's often a good idea to use enums as keys, rather than String-s. If String-s are used for keys (names) by components that will be reused on several places, then to avoid accidental name clashes, the names should use a prefix similar to a package name, like like "com.example.myframework.".

        The values of custom settings should be immutable, or at least not changed after they were added as a custom setting value. To store custom state information (such as application or framework specific caches) you should use the methods provided by CustomStateScope instead.

        The FreeMarker core doesn't provide any means for accessing custom settings from the templates. If a framework or application needs such functionality, it has to add its own custom directives/methods for that. But its more typical that custom settings just influence the behavior of custom directives/methods without the normal templates directly accessing them, or that they are just used by the framework code that invokes templates.

        Parameters:
        key - The identifier (usually an enum or a String) of the custom setting; not null; must be usable as HashMap key
        Returns:
        The value of the custom setting; possibly null, as that's a legal attribute value. The content of the value object shouldn't be changed after it was added as an attribute (ideally, it should be an immutable object); if you need to change the content, certainly you should use the CustomStateScope API. Note that if the custom setting was created with <#ftl customSettings={...}>, then this value is already unwrapped (i.e. it's a String, or a List, or a Map, ...etc., not a FreeMarker specific class).
        Throws:
        CustomSettingValueNotSetException - if the custom setting was not set (not even to null), nor in this ProcessingConfiguration, nor in another where we inherit settings from. Use getCustomSetting(Serializable, Object) to avoid this exception.

      • getCustomSetting

        Object getCustomSetting(Serializable key,
                        Object defaultValue)
        Same as getCustomSetting(Serializable), but instead of throwing CustomSettingValueNotSetException it returns the default value specified as the 2nd argument.
        Parameters:
        defaultValue - The value to return if the attribute is not set. Note that an attribute that was explicitly set to null, then null will be returned for it, not the default value specified here, since the attribute was set. If you want to know if the value was set, MISSING_VALUE_MARKER can be used, as it's guaranteed that an attribute never has that value.

      • isCustomSettingSet

        boolean isCustomSettingSet(Serializable key)
        Tells if this custom setting is set directly in this object (not in its parent ProcessingConfiguration). If not, then depending on the implementing class, reading the custom attribute might returns the value of the setting from a parent object, or returns null, or throws a CoreSettingValueNotSetException. Note that if an attribute was set to null (as opposed to not set at all) then this method will return true.

      • getCustomSettings

        Map<Serializable,Object> getCustomSettings(boolean includeInherited)
        Collects all getCustomSetting(Serializable) custom settings} into a Map (which is a snapshot); mostly useful for debugging and tooling, and is possibly too slow to call very frequently.
        Parameters:
        includeInherited - If false, only the custom settings set in this ProcessingConfiguration will be collected, otherwise the custom settings inherited from the parent ProcessingConfiguration-s will be too. Note that it's the last that matches the behavior of getCustomSetting(Serializable).
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable and unchanging Map; not null. The object identity of keys and values of this Map will not change when custom settings are set/unset later (it's a snapshot). But, if a key or value objects are themselves mutable objects, FreeMarker can't prevent their content from changing. You shouldn't change the content of those objects.
